column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1 .
#Text=Introduction
#Text=Dairy cows ’ gait characteristics are affected by their claw health as well as the surface on which they are walking .
#Text=Claw problems cause lameness , which is one of the most important dairy cow welfare issues and is associated with a decrease in walking speed and stride length .

#Text=For instance , mildly and moderately lame cows have been shown to walk slower than sound ones ( 5 % and 11 % slower , respectively ) , and moderately lame cows use shorter strides than sound and mildly lame ones ( 10 % and 8 % shorter , respectively ) .
#Text=Lameness is commonly associated with painful claws ( in 67 % of the cases ) .
#Text=Specific painful claw conditions have also been shown to decrease walking speed and stride length ( e. g. , cows with sole ulcers walked 19 % slower using 7 % shorter strides ) .
#Text=Painful claws can also occur on sound limbs , although this is less common ( 23 % of the cases ) and the pain is less severe .
#Text=Floor type also affects walking speed and stride length , which is at least partially due to alleviation of discomfort by softer ( i. e. , more compressible ) , less abrasive floor types .
#Text=Cows have been estimated to walk 4 – 6 % faster on rubber than on concrete ( although in one study , a higher walking speed was only noted when both floor types were slatted ) .
#Text=Stride length has been estimated to be 3 – 5 % longer on rubber than on concrete .

#Text=In line with the suggestion that softer floor types alleviate some of the pain associated with lameness , cows with more severe signs of lameness showed the greatest increase in stride length when walking on rubber instead of concrete , and cows ’ mobility score is improved when walking on rubber .
#Text=It has been suggested that cows reduce their speed when walking on concrete floors to reduce the impact on the hooves when these hit the floor .
#Text=Although increased walking speed and stride length often coincide , this is not necessarily the case .

#Text=For instance , studies comparing solid rubber to solid concrete reported that stride length was greater on rubber , but speed was higher on concrete , or that stride length increased significantly , whereas only a numerical increase occurred for walking speed .
#Text=In some cases , discrepancies between walking speed and stride length may occur because the tested floor types differ not only in softness and abrasiveness , but also in other characteristics .
#Text=Slipperiness also affects gait characteristics , which is likely because cows adjust their gait to reduce the chance of slipping and falling .
#Text=Slipperiness is itself affected by the softness and abrasiveness of the floor .
#Text=Softer floors that claws can sink into have been suggested to be the most effective in reducing slipperiness , and also reduce discomfort due to pressure on the claws .
#Text=Thus , both characteristics would be expected to influence walking speed and stride length in the same direction .
#Text=However , slipperiness can also be reduced by making a floor more abrasive , which may make claw – surface contact more aversive .
#Text=When bauxite aggregates were added to an epoxy resin floor , making it both less slippery and more abrasive , stride length was 5 % greater , but walking speed was 5 % lower .
#Text=The increased stride length was interpreted as an attempt to minimise contact with the floor .
#Text=The friction and abrasiveness of a floor is reported to be more strongly correlated to stride length than to walking speed .

#Text=As the relationship between gait characteristics and how a cow experiences a walking surface is complex , assessing cows ’ preferences for different floor types can provide important additional information , allowing a more correct interpretation of changes in gait .
#Text=Dairy cows are likely to avoid less comfortable surfaces , and are known to prefer rubber over concrete flooring , both when standing and walking .
#Text=Although this preference would be expected to be stronger in cows with painful claws , the opposite was found when cows ’ preferences were evaluated in a group setting .

#Text=This may have been due to competition between sound cows and lame ones , during which the sound cows would be more successful in claiming a space on the preferred floor type , as lameness reduces dominance rank .
#Text=Cows showed no significant preference for epoxy resin floors with and without added aggregates ( which decreased slipperiness but increased abrasiveness ) .
#Text=This may indicate that although cows will adapt their walking pattern to such floors , they can do so in a satisfactory way and therefore feel no need to avoid these .
